title: 112_hr1612
content: The Commission on Urotrauma is established. The Commission on Urotrauma is established by the Secretary of Defense to conduct a study on urotrauma among members of the Armed Forces and veterans, including analyzing incidence, duration, morbidity rate, mortality rate, social and economic costs, and effects of urotrauma. The Commission on Urotrauma, established by the Secretary of Defense, evaluates facilities, resources, personnel, and research related to urotrauma diagnosis, prevention, and treatment. It also assesses programs for improving prevention and treatment, develops a long-term plan for federal resources, and updates a 2011 study on urotrauma. The Committee consists of 19 members appointed by the Secretary of Defense. The Commission on Urotrauma, established by the Secretary of Defense, consists of 16 appointed members, including representatives from the Department of Health and Human Services, Walter Reed National Military Medical Center, and the Department of Veterans Affairs. Additionally, there are three nonvoting ex officio members from the Navy, Army, and Air Force Surgeon Generals. The Commission on Urotrauma, established by the Secretary of Defense, consists of 16 appointed members with relevant experience in studying or researching urotrauma, preventing or treating urotrauma. Members include representatives from various organizations such as the Surgeon General of the Air Force, Medical Officer of the Marine Corps, and Directors of the National Institutes of Health. The Commission on Urotrauma, established by the Secretary of Defense, consists of 16 appointed members with relevant experience in studying, preventing, or treating urotrauma. Members serve for life, vacancies are filled as per original appointment, and members serve without pay except for travel expenses. The Commission on Urotrauma, established by the Secretary of Defense, consists of 16 appointed members with relevant experience. A majority of members constitute a quorum, with the Secretary designating a chairperson. The Commission shall meet at the chairperson's call and have a director appointed by the chairperson. Additional staff may be appointed as deemed appropriate. The Commission on Urotrauma, established by the Secretary of Defense, consists of 16 appointed members with relevant experience. A majority of members constitute a quorum, with the Secretary designating a chairperson. The director and staff of the Commission shall be appointed in accordance with civil service laws, and experts and consultants can be procured as needed. Federal agencies may detail personnel to assist the Commission upon request. The Commission may hold hearings, take testimony, administer oaths, and receive evidence as needed to carry out its duties. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Commission can obtain necessary information from US departments or agencies. The Commission can request information from US departments or agencies to carry out its duties. It can also use the United States mails and receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. Additionally, the Commission is required to submit an interim report to the appropriate congressional body within one year of appointing its members. The Commission must submit an interim report to Congress within one year and a final report with recommendations on urotrauma prevention and treatment for Armed Forces and veterans within two years. The Commission will terminate 60 days after submitting the final report. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate. The term "urotrauma" is defined as injury to the urinary tract from various causes. Authorization of appropriations is set at $1,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2012 to 2015 for this section. The appropriation for operation and maintenance, Defense-wide, for the Office of the Secretary of Defense for fiscal years 2012 through 2015 is reduced by $1,000,000.
